titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jeremy Bold Occupy Wall Street Collection TAM.622
titlestmt.author: Rachel Schimke

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-11-30 14:32:35 -0500.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.unittitle: Jeremy Bold Occupy Wall Street Collection

physdesc.extent: in one record carton, one manuscript box, 3 oversize flat boxes, 1 artifact box, and xx oversize folders

did.langmaterial: Most materials are in English, but there are many flyers in Spanish.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open with the exception of box 1; repository permission is required for access to box 1.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: This collection was donated by Jeremy Bold in circa 2012. The accession number associated with this gift is 2012.060.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. Many materials were arranged by the donor according to the specific OWS group that generated the documents or the location where the documents were created or collected.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Jeremy "Jez" Bold is a librarian who has been actively involved with the Occupy Movement since its inception in New York City. He was involved with the organization New Yorkers Against Budget Cuts (NYABC) and their occupation near City Hall called Bloombergville in June 2011, which protested the city's proposed cuts to education and social services. Due to his affiliation with NYABC, Bold attended the Speak-Out and People's Assembly at Bowling Green Park on August 2, 2011, a gathering which was later recognized as the first General Assembly for Occupy Wall Street. Inspired by the artistry of protestors at Bloombergville, Bold proposed the creation of an OWS Arts and Culture Working Group at the Second General Assembly. Bold continues to spearhead the development of an OWS archive as a member of the Archives Working Group.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; Jeremy Bold Occupy Wall Street Collection; TAM 622; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection is unprocessed. Materials have been rehoused into archival quality boxes and folders. Separation of materials into oversized boxes is indicated with separation notes. Folder titles added by the archivist are denoted with square brackets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Occupy Wall Street materials collected by Jeremy Bold and other individuals involved with the movement provide insight into the movement's motivations and goals, organizational structures, and diverse membership. The collection consists mostly of printed ephemera and organizing materials related to the various branches of the Occupy Wall Street Movement. Most of the materials were generated by branches of the movement in New York City, but there are also materials from the movements in Minneapolis-St. Paul and Seattle. Also included are notes from meetings of the NYC Occupy Wall Street working groups, especially the Structure and Archives Working Groups. There are several large posters and pieces of artwork created for various Occupy marches and other events. The collection also contains several publications regarding the Occupy movement, both third-party coverage and publications generated by the movement itself.

To a lesser extent, the collection includes publicity and organizing materials related to other social justice causes, such as immigration and housing rights, and informational materials on anarchism. There are also some materials generated by the organization New Yorkers Against Budget Cuts (NYABC), which organized an occupation near NYC's City Hall called Bloombergville in June 2011, and an offshoot Occupy group called Occupy Museums.
Researchers may find the following list of abbreviations useful when determining where materials were generated or collected:

#M1GS = May 1 General Strike MSP/TC = Minneapolis-St. Paul/Twin Cities #S17, #S17NY, #S17NYC = Events planned for Sept. 15-17, 2012 in NYC to commemorate one year anniversary of the movement #D17 = Occupation of Duarte Square Park on December 17, 2011, the three month anniversary of the movement AP = Andrea's Place MM = Magic Mountain LP = Liberty Plaza BKC = Brooklyn College? NYU BL = New York University Bobst Library GA = General Assembly

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Runs of periodicals generated by the Occupy movement, such as The Occupied Wall Street Journal, were separated for library cataloging.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright (or related rights to publicity and privacy) for materials in this collection, created by Jeremy Bold, was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.

accessrestrict.p: Repository permission is required for access to box 1. Please contact Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive, tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu, 212-998-2630.
